Recommendation: Use a sulfur or copper-based fungicide at bud break. Prune and destroy fallen leaves to reduce overwintering spores.
Prune out and destroy infected limbs and dead wood. Apply general-purpose fungicide (e.g.
column3: Captan) during bloom and at 7-14 day intervals.

Recommendation: Plant resistant varieties. Apply fungicides containing myclobutanil or propiconazole at bloom and during moist periods. Remove nearby cedar trees if possible.
No action needed. Continue routine care and monitoring.
No action needed. This image is not of a leaf.

Apply horticultural oil or sulfur-based fungicide as soon as symptoms appear. Ensure good air circulation around the canopy.
No action needed. Continue routine care and monitoring.
Apply a fungicide containing triazoles or strobilurins when disease severity reaches the threshold (usually at tasseling). Rotate crops annually.
For severe outbreaks
column3: apply a fungicide containing propiconazole or pyraclostrobin. Use resistant corn hybrids if available.

Recommendation: Apply fungicides (e.g.
column3: strobilurins) from late-whorl to tasseling stages. Use crop rotation and tillage to bury infected residue.

Recommendation: No action needed. Continue routine care and monitoring.
Apply protective fungicides (e.g.
column3: mancozeb or captan) every 7–10 days from pre-bloom through veraison. Remove all infected berries and canes.

Recommendation: Prune out all symptomatic wood. Apply wood protectant sealants to large pruning wounds. Use cultural practices to reduce stress.
Apply fungicides containing copper or sulfur as a preventative measure during the growing season. Ensure proper vine ventilation.
No action needed. Continue routine care and monitoring.
There is no cure. Manage Asian Citrus Psyllid (ACP) vectors with systemic insecticides (e.g.
column3: imidacloprid). Remove infected trees to prevent spread.

Recommendation: Apply copper sprays early in the season. Prune to improve air circulation and use resistant varieties.
No action needed. Continue routine care and monitoring.
Apply copper sprays starting when leaves emerge. Use disease-free seeds and transplants. Avoid overhead irrigation.
No action needed. Continue routine care and monitoring.
Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil every 7–10 days starting at bloom. Use crop rotation and adequate fertilization.
Apply systemic fungicides (e.g.
column4: mandipropamid) immediately upon forecast or detection. Destroy infected plant material completely.

Recommendation: No action needed. Continue routine care and monitoring.

Apply fungicides (e.g.
column3: containing sulfur or potassium bicarbonate) weekly. Use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering.

Recommendation: Apply foliar fungicides such as copper or captan. Remove infected older leaves and ensure good soil drainage.

Apply copper-based fungicides weekly. Avoid working near plants when they are wet to prevent spread.
Apply protective fungicides (e.g.
column3: chlorothalonil) when the first spots appear. Rotate crops and remove lower leaves near the soil.

Recommendation: Use prescribed systemic fungicides immediately. Use certified disease-free transplants and destroy all infected debris.
Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or copper. Ensure good ventilation in greenhouses or high-density plantings.
Apply chlorothalonil or copper-based sprays every 7–14 days. Remove infected leaves immediately.
Apply horticultural oils or insecticidal soaps. For severe cases
column3: use selective miticides. Increase humidity if possible.

Recommendation: Apply mancozeb or chlorothalonil fungicides. Increase air circulation and reduce leaf wetness.
Control whitefly vectors using insecticides (e.g.
column3: permethrin). Remove and destroy all infected plants.

Recommendation: There is no chemical cure. Remove infected plants. Disinfect tools with a 10% bleach solution after handling infected material.
No action needed. Continue routine care and monitoring.
